hints_html:
The average value for a function \(f(x)\) is defined by

\[\begin{aligned} f_{av} = \frac{1}{b-a}\int_{a}^{b}f(x)\, dx\end{aligned}\]
hints_raw:
The average value for a function <math> f(x) </math> is defined by

:<math>
f_{av} = \frac{1}{b-a}\int_{a}^{b}f(x)\, dx
</math>
question: 1 (d)
sols_html:
Using the hint, we have

\[\begin{aligned} f_{av} &= \frac{1}{\pi/k-0}\int_{0}^{\pi/k}\sin(kx)\, dx\\ &= \frac{k}{\pi}\left.\left(\frac{-1}{k}\cos(kx) \right)\right|_{0}^{\pi/k}\\ &= \frac{-1}{\pi}\left( \cos(\pi) - \cos(0) \right)\\ &= \frac{-1}{\pi}( -1 -1)\\ &= \frac{2}{\pi}\end{aligned}\]
statement_html:
Short-Answer Question. Show all your work, simplify your answer as much as possible.

Let k be a positive constant. Find the average value of the function \(f(x) = \sin(kx)\) on the interval \([0,\pi/k]\)
statement_latex:
\textbf{Short-Answer Question.} Show all your work, simplify your answer
as much as possible.

Let \emph{k} be a positive constant. Find the average value of the
function $f(x) = \sin(kx)$ on the interval $[0,\pi/k]$
statement_raw:
'''Short-Answer Question.''' Show all your work, simplify your answer as much as possible.

Let ''k'' be a positive constant. Find the average value of the function <math> f(x) = \sin(kx) </math> on the interval <math> [0,\pi/k] </math>
